]]> No publisher ab98 Distance Learning News Event CIPD LLM Employment Law 2014-10-30T12:25:00Z News Item Armed Conflict Learning shortlisted for national e-learning award http://www2.le.ac.uk/colleges/socsci/college%20news/armed-conflict-learning-shortlisted-for-national-e-learning-award University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Criminology has been shortlisted from a respected list of international entries for the 2013 e-learning Awards \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdBest Use of Mobile Learning\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. How do you reach professionals wanting to further their knowledge of conflict prevention and recovery issues \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd while living and working in remote and hazardous areas, including places affected by armed conflict? This was the challenge facing University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Criminology and their new distance learning MSc in Security, Conflict and International Development (SCID).

Head of the Department of Criminology, Professor Adrian Beck explains:

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe understood that our existing distance learning model of printed and online resources didn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt match the needs of students, many of whom are based overseas, on the move and without access to the internet.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Take a look at our video about how and why\ufffd\ufffdwe developed the App for our MSc in Security, Conflict and International Development

The answer was deceptively simple. To reach people working for the UN, government and aid agencies and NGOs in conflict or post-conflict countries, the Department gave all their students an iPad, loaded with a course App containing all their course materials and links to further reading.

And the results have been impressive. Since its launch in March 2012, course recruitment is 100% above target, and the Department is planning further similar initiatives. Students using the App have shown that they are accessing more learning materials than before. Retention and failure rates have also improved significantly.

Professor Beck continues:

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdSince we gave our students the iPads and launched the App-based course, the response has been remarkable \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd they\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre reading more, because they\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre able to. I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm seeing much lower rates of failure from students and course tutors are commenting on the students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd engagement and commitment\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

The winners of the eLearning Award will be announced at a gala event on November 7th at the London Marriott Hotel Grosvenor Square.

More information about our MSc in Security, Conflict and International Development

2013 eLearning Award Shortlist

The University of Leicester is also shortlisted in the award for Best Online distance learning programme, for its partnership with the BMJ to offer an online Distance Learning programme for Diabetes Qualifications.

]]> No publisher rd251 College:SocSci Distance Learning Criminology 2013-09-23T14:55:00Z Blog Entry Diabetes qualification partnership shortlisted for e-learning award http://www2.le.ac.uk/staff/community/people/staffupdates/2013/september/university-of-leicester-partnership-shortlisted-for-e-learning-award Partnership with British Medical Journal shortlisted for Best Online Distance Learning Programme A partnership between the British Medical Journal and academics from the Departments of Health Sciences and Cardiovascular Sciences to provide an online distance learning programme for the Diabetes Qualifications has been shortlisted for an E-Learning award.

The Diabetes Qualifications are validated by the University of Leicester, with students receiving a Postgraduate Certificate or Postgraduate Diploma in Diabetes from the University.

Both Professor Melanie Davies and Professor Kamlesh Khunti are Course Directors, with over 450 students from over 40 countries who have taken or are currently on the programme. The programme has been shortlisted for the Best Online Distance Learning Programme award for:

  • excellent use of online media and tools to facilitate learning.
  • a range of methods and media have been employed over many weeks or months of part-time study, typically leading to a formal qualification
  • appropriate choices have been made with regard to online tools and techniques and the use of media within the materials
  • support has been effectively provided to learners by tutors and facilitators;
  • collaboration between learners has been effectively encouraged and facilitated; and
  • the use of online tools and techniques has achieved the required results in terms of learner satisfaction, take-up and pass rates

The programme of courses are based on the International Diabetes Federation's (IDF) curriculum, and have been designed to address the needs of healthcare professionals from around the world and from across the multi-disciplinary team.

]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Student Archaeology Magazine:Staff Distance Learning Sports 2013-04-17T10:17:58Z Blog Entry Leicester enlists soldiers with a passion for archaeology http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/august/leicester-enlists-soldiers-with-a-passion-for-archaeology Soldiers injured in Afghanistan have taken up degrees in archaeology at the University as part of their recovery.

The soldiers, who have suffered physical and psychological injuries on operations, have been involved in archaeological excavation as a form of occupational activity.

Now, the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds School of Archaeology and Ancient History are offering a special fee scheme to these soldiers to aid their studies. A number of service men and women have already signed up and more are expected to enrol in October. Their degree now means that they will be able to access resources and academic texts whilst they are studying.

Their interest in archaeology stems from Operation Nightingale, an award winning project previously reported on the Newsblog. The idea originated with Diarmaid Walshe, an infantryman and qualified archaeologist and was run in partnership with the Defence Infrastructure Organisation (DIO).

The scheme also helps soldiers in their future career development when they leave the army and, as their degree is delivered via distance learning, has allowed them to combine their studies with excavation work in the field.

]]> No publisher pcweb1 Postgraduate Psychology Distance Learning 2012-06-12T10:20:00Z Page Presentation of awards to Maltese distance learning graduates http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/may/presentation-of-awards-to-maltese-distance-learner-graduates Human Resources students benefit from Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds internationally accessible courses. Undergraduate and postgraduate students in Malta who studied on our Human Resources courses by distance learning have received their qualifications at a ceremony on the island.

Our Centre for Labour Market Studies has a long-standing relationship with the Foundation for Human Resources Development and Dr Nalita James from the CLMS flew out to the Mediterranean to attend the presentations. Nalita and Ms Annika Galea President of the FHRD, presented the students with their certificates.

Eleven students received a Masters Degree in Human Resources, eight graduated from the BSc course and a further eleven received Diplomas or Certificates.

MSc graduate Veronica Farrugia, who obtained a distinction in her dissertation and had the highest overall assignment average amongst the Masters graduates, was presented with the Louis Naudi Award. Louis Naudi was HR director of the Island Hotels Group and a founder member of the FHRD.

The presentation was reported by local media including the Malta Star.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Labour Market Studies HR Distance Learning Magazine:Student 2012-05-21T10:44:56Z Blog Entry Bullet-proof vests and iPads: criminology in a conflict zone http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/march/criminology-pilots-use-of-ipads-and-apps-to-aid-learning-in-conflict-zones Our Department of Criminology is now offering distance learning courses via mobile app in post-war countries. You may think that safely learning about international security, the rule of law and human rights in a country which has recently been a war-zone would be a challenging feat. But with the recent efforts of the Head of our Department of Criminology, Adrian Beck, and his team of academics, the University is now able to offer a distance learning MSc in Security, Conflict and International Development to international development workers who are based in post-conflict countries, or those who are interested in this field of work.

The wonders of modern technology mea that the course, which focuses on the skills, knowledge and understanding needed to work in post-conflict countries, is delivered online and via an app downloaded onto an iPad provided by the University. Students can study topics on the move even when they don't have access to the internet, and the delivery is therefore as flexible as possible to meet their needs.

The course is particularly well-timed as the multitude of social, political and cultural uprisings in the Middle East means that experts working in countries going through such transitions will be highly sought after. It also means that the University will be able to take a lead in supporting those who already work in these difficult areas and want to help countries emerge from conflicts successfully.

The first students signed up last week to the new course which is something of an experiment. If it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds successful, then the template could well be used for other courses to aid distance learning across the University, and drastically change the way students use devices such as the iPad in their studies.

  • University press release

A piece in the Guardian last week about the increased popularity of MBAs - Master of Business Administration - featured one of our current students, Shaun McCormick, founder of specialist business consultancy Tacit Pharma.

Shaun is studying for a distance learning MBA with our School of Management and has already set up his own company providing consultancy services to the pharmaceutical industry, a sector where he had previously worked as a senior manager.

So successful has Tacit been that Shaun has subsequently expanded his business empire into Tacit Recruitment and web design agency Tacit Creations.

"The MBA helped my understanding of all the factors that impact on a business and how best to navigate to grow,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Shaun told the paper. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMy MBA experiences helped me launch, finance and grow the companies, find new markets and customers and create jobs."

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Graduates in the news Management Distance Learning Magazine:Student 2011-11-21T15:10:00Z Blog Entry Totally tropical: bringing the University of Leicester to the Caribbean http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/november/totally-tropical-bringing-the-university-of-leicester-to-the-caribbean School of Management staff visit distance learners on distant islands. Two academics from our School of Management are currently visiting the West Indies, providing lectures and academic support to current and prospective students of our distance learning management courses in some of the tiny island nations of the Caribbean.

Alan Bryman, Professor of Organisational and Social Research, and Dr Bruce Hearn, Lecturer in Finance and Corporate Governance spent a few days this week in St Kitts and Nevis, the smallest sovereign state in the Americas. The two-island country covers just 104 square miles, with a population not much over 50,000. The tour will also take in St Lucia and Barbados.

Through our distance learning courses, students around the world are able to use the resources of a leading, campus-based university without leaving home (and you can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt blame them \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the weather in Leicester right now is hardly tropical). Leicester is the second-biggest provider of distance learning courses in the UK and our management courses are particularly popular, especially the Masters of Business Administration (MBA).

During their stay, Professor Bryman and Dr Hearn spoke about leadership models and learning strategies as well as providing an \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdacademic help desk\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for students currently studying, or interested in, our popular MBA by distance learning. At a press conference in Basseterre, capital of St Kitts and Nevis, Professor Bryman told local news site SKNVibes:

The purpose of this visit is to be a visible face of the University and the School; we lecture to the students, we provide dissertation support to students who are at that stage in their degrees. We provide them with information about how to approach dissertation, how to study and they can come to us with any difficulties they are experiencing.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

And Dr Hearn told ZIZ, the country\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds national broadcaster:

We see it as important as a provision for people who want to study for a higher degree but who don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt have the time or the opportunity to take one or two years out of a very busy program; a programme of work, a programme of family responsibilities, but who do want to study.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The visit was organised by our partner in the Caribbean, Florida-based Education for Advancement.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Management Distance Learning Magazine:Student 2011-11-11T11:09:25Z Blog Entry MSc Security, Conflict and International Development http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/criminology/dlcourses/pgdlcourses/msc_security_conflict_international_development/msc_security_conflict_international_development \ufffd\ufffd

Programme Outline

\ufffd\ufffd

Key Facts

Mode: Distance learning

Entry Requirements: 2:2 or above or equivalent qualification

Fees: \ufffd\ufffd10,365 - UK/EU, \ufffd\ufffd12,455 - International,\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd9,635 - International Discount- see Eligible Countries

Application Deadline: 20 August 2015

Course Start Date: 7 September 2015

Length of Course: 2 years

This innovative and exciting new postgraduate degree programme focuses on how to meet the strategic security and justice challenges of countries emerging from conflict. Designed specifically for those working - or hoping to work - in international development, the programme seeks to develop skills, knowledge and understanding of conflict prevention and recovery with a particular emphasis upon: responding to the challenges of countries emerging from conflict; security sector reform; how to develop the rule of law; the importance of human rights in delivering justice and security; and broader issues relating to international security and the risks posed by countries emerging from, and vulnerable to, conflict.

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

Find out more about our programme from our Staff and Students by clicking on the video below!

This promotional video was filmed and edited by Tide Productions

Next Steps: Download the Security, Conflict and International Development Brochure

Using state-of-the-art learning technologies, the MSc in Security, Conflict and International Development provides students with the opportunity to develop their professional careers in an area of growing strategic importance.

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

The programme is designed to give students the opportunity to develop a broad range of knowledge and skills including:

  • detailed understanding of a\ufffd\ufffdbroad range of issues relating to\ufffd\ufffdsecurity, conflict and international development.
  • awareness of key concepts associated with security, conflict and\ufffd\ufffdinternational development and\ufffd\ufffdcapability of applying knowledge and understanding in workplace situations and to new contexts and environments.
  • ability to analyse\ufffd\ufffdkey theoretical approaches to understanding the causes of conflict and evaluating the appropriateness of preventative methods in this field.
  • understanding of the ways in which to respond to the challenges of conflict and immediate post-conflict environments.
  • comprehensive understanding of post-conflict recovery efforts in the security and justice sectors, combined with an awareness of concurrent political, economic, development and humanitarian efforts.
  • capability to present knowledge and arguments clearly, confidently, coherently and concisely using a variety of communication formats.
  • ability to assess the appropriateness of the evidence and the methods used in studies relating to security, conflict and international development, including their value and limitations.
  • ability to undertake analysis and reflect on critically and contextually on material related to security, conflict and international development.

\ufffd\ufffd

Course Structure and Assessment

The MSc programme is studied part-time over two years. The course consists of six\ufffd\ufffdmodules, all of which must be successfully completed to qualify the Postgraduate Diploma in Security, Conflict and International Development. To progress to the MSc degree a dissertation must also be successfully completed.

The MSc Security, Conflict and International Development programme is based on continuous assessment, with each of the six modules comprising an e-tivity - an online activity which comprises 20 per cent of the mark, and a written paper of not more than 3,500 words. Each module lasts around 12 weeks, three weeks of which are intended for you to write your assignments.\ufffd\ufffdYou will have approximately five months to complete your dissertation, which can be a topic of your choosing (subject to agreement with your supervisor).

Module 1 Conflict Prevention, Response and Recovery
Module 2 Post-Conflict Rule of Law and Security
Module 3 Research Methods in Security, Conflict and International Development
Module\ufffd\ufffd4 Security Sector Reform
Module 5 Human Rights, Justice and Security
Module 6 International Security Risks
Dissertation

We have been made aware that a very small number of countries currently restrict access to certain online content and content providers that are necessary to enable users to receive our Course App as well as download some of the electronic text books we provide as part of this course. While this is beyond the control of the University of Leicester, it should be noted that all the necessary resources to study on this course can still be accessed via the University's Virtual Learning Environment \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Blackboard. In addition, where a student cannot receive electronic versions of text books, hard copy versions will be sent directly to students. If you think this affects you and would like to discuss your particular circumstances, please contact the Department of Criminology at criminology@le.ac.uk.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Media and Communications Distance Learning Magazine:Student 2011-04-19T10:35:21Z Blog Entry Leicester: a model for the future of higher education? http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/january/leicester-a-model-for-the-future-of-higher-education Online learning looks set to change the UK higher education sector dramatically in the coming years, but a report out today suggests that the University of Leicester may be better prepared than most. The Higher Education Funding Council for England\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Online Learning Task Force has used the University of Leicester as a case study for the implementation of a strategy for e-learning, and highlighted our 20 successful years of distance learning provision.

The HEFCE report Collaborate to Compete calls on universities to work together to find ways of offering students more flexible ways of studying, or risk losing ground to overseas or private institutions.

The report argues that more investment in online and distance learning by universities is needed and institutions should now be looking to form collaborations with successful providers.

Distance learning programmes at the University of Leicester are flexible, high quality and focused on students and their needs. Eighteen thousand students have graduated from its distance learning programmes and more than 8,000 are currently studying. The university encourages the formation of networks of students as a vital source of peer support."

For more analysis of the report, see the expanded online feature on our Press Office website.

]]> No publisher pt91 Magazine:Staff E-Learning Distance Learning Magazine:Student 2011-01-27T17:05:00Z Blog Entry Leicester named as preferred supplier for government MBAs http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2010-archive/september-2010/leicester-named-as-preferred-supplier-for-government-mbas Public sector approval for highly rated distance learning course. The University of Leicester has been named as one of only three \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpreferred suppliers\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of distance learning MBAs to the public sector in the UK.

The Government has announced, through its procurement body Buying Solutions, a framework agreement with the University to provide the Master of Business Administration qualification by distance learning to customers in central government, regional government and the wider public sector. The only other Higher Education Institutions with similar agreements are Henley Business School and the Open University. A further six institutions are preferred suppliers for part-time, campus-based MBAs.

Buying Solutions is the national procurement partner for all UK public services and is part of the Efficiency and Reform Group within the Cabinet Office. Its selection of MBA providers was based on both quality of teaching and value for money.

The Leicester distance learning MBA is accredited by the Association of MBAs (AMBA) and is one of our most popular courses. It is run by our School of Management.
